Why android version of "Final Fantasy IV: The After Years" different from iphone version (IOS)? No update (old version) and more importantly "NO 3D Cutscene/film scene".. The scene is important for the game to enrich game experience.. Please add the 3D cinematic scene and please update the game (like newer android version of Final Fantasy III and Final Fantasy IV).. Like Playstation Portable (PSP) version too (much complete with 3D cutscene)..

*spoilers* Awesome follow up to final fantasy IV i couldn't stop playing it. The story was captivating and I like the remastered graphics. Sadly however there are some issues i encountered a soft lock during the lunar bahamut fight where after killing him his meteor killed me. His death animation played and i couldn't do anything but close and reopen the game. I also find the games lack of optional bosses disappointing as FFIV had 2 bosses you could fight during new game + this has none.

I love FFIV remake , but i hate this remake. The pace and style is too slow and boring. I really dislike the chapter style for each character. There isnt much level design in each chapter to encourage exploration game is extremely linear.

Very enjoyable game with in-depth game play and great graphics. A must for any Final Fantasy fan.  The touch controls are generally good but there are some quirks.  When clicking treasure chests, I tend to mis-click a lot and end up changing my character instead (what is the point of changing the on-screen character anyway?). Finding the option to use a weapon (i.e. healing rod) as an item is not obvious and Help makes no mention of how to do this.  Finally, there is no way to quit out of a game and load another one without closing the app. My other complaint is that the game seems to experience slowdowns during battle sometimes which can get irritating.  Overall, a very enjoyable game and the hours of game-play you will get out of it makes it worth the premium price.

I played FF IV (or II) on the SNES many times as a teenager and it was great. This game got my attention and I knew I would be playing it soon enough. I definitely like the look of this version better compared to the others that came out. I am playing this on my ten inch Samsung tablet and it's great, can't imagine any other way. After reading some of the negative reviews I do agree on many parts. The different stories with the characters aren't anything memorable and it seems repetitive. I guess it's nice to see some new characters, mostly just kids that the older characters had and the two twins from the previous game that grew up (I thought they turned themselves into stone though). The part that really sucks is how a lot of the same music was reused. I haven't heard anything new. Overall it's not a bad game for at least one play through. I am glad I bought this at a discounted price.

I'll get the good parts out of the way first - the new moon phase mechanic adds some variety to the fighting (granted it doesn't add anything else), and the great looks of FFIV remain as well. 95% of everything else was also pulled from FFIV. You'll play the same characters in the same towns using the same items - and hilariously, you'll even have to beat the same dungeons multiple times to go through this nonsensical, lead-you-by-the-nose story. You'll play the vast majority of the game with low-level characters, and grinding is an absolute chore. This is a 40 hour game, and all you've played all 40 hours already. No voice overs, the same music... a complete rehash of IV, with an insane random encounter rate. For completists and masochists only.

FF4, while not bad, is super overrated. It doesn't play or flow very well, mechanically or narratively. Its sequel is worse, adding in a Band combo attack system that's often way less effective than just using attacks/spells, rarely making use of your five party slots, and separating the game into individual chapters instead of a more cohesive whole. Fun in very small bursts. Lack of gamepad support really, really hurts; I bought my Nvidia Shield to use its controls, not its touch screen. Disappointing from a company that sees fit to massively overcharge for its mobile games.

This game is good, models are great, music is fun to listen to, and the battle system is so much fun. Unfortunately with this remake, the band system has been dumb down, the maps have been reduced, challenge dungeons are gone, and the bosses from Final Fantasy I-VI from the original have been replaced with three Lunar Eidolons that offer no real challenge.  Good remake, but the 2011 PSP version is still the definitive version of the After Years.

FOR is my favorite in the series. The 3D remake of FF4AY let's you get the total experience of the game. Game has very good story and is definitely a must own for fans of the series.  I own this title on all platforms from Wii to emulators to mobile. Must say great remake.

This Final Fantasy is like the 2005 Blockbuster, King Kong - about 50% longer than it needs to be. I started out really enjoying After Years. However, the further you venture into the game, the more repetitive it becomes. You have to walk through the same dungeons over and over again. Oh I just spent over an hour walking through a cave to Kaipo, but have to immediately return through it in its entirety to get a stupid sand pearl on the other side, exactly where I was an hour ago?  Fun times. Also, pretty much half the game is the final dungeon. If you thought the lunar subterranean had too many levels in the original FFIV, you'll be in for a wild ride in the after years. Pretty sure I entered back when George W Bush was still President and I still haven't reached the bottom. I am close to just throwing in the towel. Besides my rant on repetitiveness, this game is markedly easier than its predecessor. I'm giving it a generous three stars.
